name: mustang-panda

procedures: T1003.003::[Mustang Panda] has used vssadmin to create a volume shadow copy and retrieve the NTDS.dit file. [Mustang Panda] has also used reg save on the SYSTEM file Registry location to help extract the NTDS.dit file.
T1016::[Mustang Panda] has used ipconfig and arp to determine network configuration information.
T1027.001::[Mustang Panda] has used junk code within their DLL files to hinder analysis.
T1027::[Mustang Panda] has delivered initial payloads hidden using archives and encoding measures.
T1036.005::[Mustang Panda] has used names like `adobeupdate.dat` and `PotPlayerDB.dat` to disguise [PlugX], and a file named `OneDrive.exe` to load a [Cobalt Strike] payload.
T1036.007::[Mustang Panda] has used an additional filename extension to hide the true file type.
T1047::[Mustang Panda] has executed PowerShell scripts via WMI.
T1049::[Mustang Panda] has used netstat -ano to determine network connection information.
T1052.001::[Mustang Panda] has used a customized [PlugX] variant which could exfiltrate documents from air-gapped networks.
T1053.005::[Mustang Panda] has created a scheduled task to execute additional malicious software, as well as maintain persistence.
T1057::[Mustang Panda] has used tasklist /v to determine active process information.
T1059.001::[Mustang Panda] has used malicious PowerShell scripts to enable execution.
T1059.003::[Mustang Panda] has executed HTA files via cmd.exe, and used batch scripts for collection.
T1059.005::[Mustang Panda] has embedded VBScript components in LNK files to download additional files and automate collection.
T1070.004::[Mustang Panda] will delete their tools and files, and kill processes after their objectives are reached.
T1071.001::[Mustang Panda] has communicated with its C2 via HTTP POST requests.
T1074.001::[Mustang Panda] has stored collected credential files in c:\windows\temp prior to exfiltration. [Mustang Panda] has also stored documents for exfiltration in a hidden folder on USB drives.
T1082::[Mustang Panda] has gathered system information using systeminfo.
T1083::[Mustang Panda] has searched the entire target system for DOC, DOCX, PPT, PPTX, XLS, XLSX, and PDF files.
T1091::[Mustang Panda] has used a customized [PlugX] variant which could spread through USB connections.
T1102::[Mustang Panda] has used DropBox URLs to deliver variants of [PlugX].
T1105::[Mustang Panda] has downloaded additional executables following the initial infection stage.
T1119::[Mustang Panda] used custom batch scripts to collect files automatically from a targeted system.
T1203::[Mustang Panda] has exploited CVE-2017-0199 in Microsoft Word to execute code.
T1204.001::[Mustang Panda] has sent malicious links including links directing victims to a Google Drive folder.
T1204.002::[Mustang Panda] has sent malicious files requiring direct victim interaction to execute.
T1218.004::[Mustang Panda] has used InstallUtil.exe to execute a malicious Beacon stager.
T1218.005::[Mustang Panda] has used mshta.exe to launch collection scripts.
T1219::[Mustang Panda] has installed TeamViewer on targeted systems.
T1518::[Mustang Panda] has searched the victim system for the InstallUtil.exe program and its version.
T1546.003::[Mustang Panda]'s custom ORat tool uses a WMI event consumer to maintain persistence.
T1547.001::[Mustang Panda] has created the registry key HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Wow6432Node\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run\AdobelmdyU to maintain persistence.
T1560.001::[Mustang Panda] has used RAR to create password-protected archives of collected documents prior to exfiltration.
T1560.003::[Mustang Panda] has encrypted documents with RC4 prior to exfiltration.
T1564.001::[Mustang Panda]'s [PlugX] variant has created a hidden folder on USB drives named RECYCLE.BIN to store malicious executables and collected data.
T1566.001::[Mustang Panda] has used spearphishing attachments to deliver initial access payloads.
T1566.002::[Mustang Panda] has delivered malicious links to their intended targets.
T1573.001::[Mustang Panda] has encrypted C2 communications with RC4.
T1574.002::[Mustang Panda] has used a legitimately signed executable to execute a malicious payload within a DLL file.
T1583.001::[Mustang Panda] have acquired C2 domains prior to operations.
T1585.002::[Mustang Panda] has leveraged the legitimate email marketing service SMTP2Go for phishing campaigns.
T1598.003::[Mustang Panda] has delivered web bugs to profile their intended targets.
T1608.001::[Mustang Panda] has hosted malicious payloads on DropBox including [PlugX].
T1608::[Mustang Panda] has used servers under their control to validate tracking pixels sent to phishing victims.

description: [Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) is a China-based cyber espionage threat actor that was first observed in 2017 but may have been conducting operations since at least 2014. [Mustang Panda](https://attack.mitre.org/groups/G0129) has targeted government entities, nonprofits, religious, and other non-governmental organizations in the U.S., Europe, Mongolia, Myanmar, Pakistan, and Vietnam, among others.(Citation: Crowdstrike MUSTANG PANDA June 2018)(Citation: Anomali MUSTANG PANDA October 2019)(Citation: Secureworks BRONZE PRESIDENT December 2019)
